{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{BLP sources|date=August 2009}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = André Azoulay |office = Senior adviser to King Mohammed VI |order =
<!----office------------------> |honorific-prefix = |honorific-suffix = |image = André Azoulay 2014 (cropped).jpg |alt = |smallimage = <!--If this is specified, "image" should not be.--> |caption = |monarch = |predecessor = |primeminister = |successor =
<!------------------------------------data----> |footnotes = |signature = |signature_alt = |party = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1941|04|17|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Essaouira]], [[Morocco]] |death_date = |death_place = |citizenship = |nationality = [[Morocco|Moroccan]] |spouse = |relations = |children = |residence = |profession = |cabinet = |committees = |portfolio = |blank1= Religion |data1 = [[Judaism |Jewish]] |website = |imagesize = |term_start = |term_end = |restingplace = |restingplacecoordinates = |birthname = }}
'''André Azoulay''' ({{lang-ar|أندري أزولاي}}, born 17 April 1941) is a senior adviser to king [[Mohammed VI]] of [[Morocco]].<ref name="election">[http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2007/861/re3.htm Fair or not?] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070911182314/http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2007/861/re3.htm |date=11 September 2007 }} Al-Ahram Weekly.</ref><ref name=Shefa>{{cite news|last1=Shefa|first1=Sheri|title=Festival to celebrate Jewish life in Morocco|url=http://www.cjnews.com/canada/festival-celebrate-jewish-life-morocco|accessdate=6 May 2015|publisher=[[Canadian Jewish News]]|date=28 May 2012}}</ref> He previously advised Mohammed's father, king [[Hassan II]]. He currently presides over the [[Anna Lindh Euro-Mediterranean Foundation for the Dialogue Between Cultures]], based in [[Alexandria, Egypt]]. He is also President of the Executive Committee of the [[Foundation for the Three Cultures and the Three Religions]], based in [[Seville, Spain]], a founding member of the C-100 Davos Forum for the Dialogue of Civilisations and religions, and was formerly Executive Vice-President of the [[BNP Paribas]], [[Paris]]. His daughter is [[UNESCO]] Director-General [[Audrey Azoulay]].
==Early life== Born in [[Essaouira]], in 1941 to a [[Moroccan Jewish]] family, André Azoulay was educated in Paris where he studied economics, journalism and international relations. Previously to his current position as Counsellor to the King of Morocco, Azoulay, had a long career within the [[Paribas]] Bank in Paris (1968 to 1990) where, as Executive Vice-President, he covered the [[MENA|Middle East and North Africa Region]] as well as heading the bank’s Public Affairs department.
As Counsellor of the late King Hassan II from (1991 to 1999), and since then of king Mohammed VI, André Azoulay has largely contributed to the implementation of economic reforms, which have been applied throughout the kingdom since their inception in the early 1990s. He also played a significant role in the privatisation and deregulation programs which began in 1993. He emphasized the need for sustaining the role of the private sector and encouraging the international investment to sustain economic growth in Morocco. Azoulay has also largely contributed to promote Morocco throughout the world.
==Peace builder== Azoulay is also known for his historical input in the follow-up of the peace process in the Middle East and the many initiatives he has been involved in the perspective of deepening the logic of reconciliation between Jews and Muslims. In addition to his professional responsibilities André Azoulay has always fought for peace and dialogue between the Arab Muslim World and that of the Jewish communities in Europe, the United States, Morocco as well as the Arab, [[Berbers|Berber]] and Jewish diasporas worldwide.
For over 40 years, Azoulay has taken an active part in supporting the activities of different movements and associations whose vocation is the [[two-state solution]] (Palestine and Israel) and to help the process of better understanding and mutual respect between Islam and the Western World.
President of the Executive Committee of the Foundation of the Three Cultures and the Three Religions based in Seville (Spain) he is one of the founders of the Aladin Group (Paris) created to promote mutual knowledge and intercultural relations among Muslims and Jews.
In August 2005, Azoulay was also nominated member of the "High Level Group" for the "Alliance of Civilizations, set up by the United Nations. Instigated by Spain and co-sponsored by Turkey, this initiative is addressing the issue of the relations between Islam and the Western world.
In this context, he was elected 5 March 2008 and reelected 9 September 2011 as President of the Euro-Mediterranean Anna Lindh Foundation, and member of the Executive Committee of the Mediterranean Council for Culture (Paris) as well as Board member of the Mediterranean Study and Research Center (Marseille) the Yala online leadership Academy and the Institut de Prospective et d’Etudes pour le Monde Méditerranéen (Paris).
Member of the Board of Al Akhawayne University (Ifrane), the Mediterranean University (Fès) and the High Council of the Alliance Israelite Universelle, Azoulay belongs to the Scientific Committee of "Medinas" a think-tank created by the World Bank and the European Investment Bank to protect, restore and promote the "Medinas" in the Arab World. He is also member of the boards of the Institute Pierre Mendès-France (Paris) and YALA (Young Araba Leaders for Peace).
Belonging to the Board of several economic and financial institutions, André Azoulay is a member of the Royal Academy of Morocco and of the Royal Academy of Spain for Economic and Financial Sciences. He has been honoured with the titles of "Commandeur dans l’Ordre du Trône" (Morocco) and he has received many awards and titles of honour throughout the world (France, Spain, Italy, Germany, U.K., Portugal, Brazil, Mexico, Argentina). André Azoulay received the Lifetime Achievement Award, from the [[American Sephardi Federation]] in New York, where [[Enrico Macias]] and [[David Serero (opera singer)|David Serero]] performed during the ceremony in his honor.<ref>https://www.moroccoworldnews.com/2017/03/210421/andre-azoulay-receive-american-sephardi-federations-lifetime-achievement-award/</ref>
==Essaouira== [[File:Gnaoua (Gnawa) musicians performing during the 2010 Gnaoua festival in the city of Essaouira, Morocco.jpg|thumb|right|Gnaoua ([[Gnawa]]) musicians performing during the 2010 [[Gnaoua World Music Festival]] in the city of [[Essaouira]], Morocco]] With his wife Katia, also born in [[Essaouira]], who published 2 books "Essaouira-Mogador : Parfums d’Enfance" and "Essaouira-Mogador : Passion partagée", he is the architect of the renaissance of the city they both hold very dear to their hearts. André Azoulay is fervent in the promotion and revival of his home town which has a specific place in the historical, cultural and spiritual heritage of Morocco. He is the founder President of the Association Essaouira-Mogador which has established since 1992 an original approach to the durable development based on its cultural diversity and spiritual legacy.
Essaouira is justly proud to host seven music festivals a year, ranging from classical to lyrical. They include the renowned [[Gnaoua World Music Festival]], the Chamber Music with "le Printemps Musical des Alizés" and the rich Judeo-Muslim repertoire of Andalusian-Atlantic Festival, a unique event in the world inviting on the same stage, every year, poets, musicians and singers, Muslims and Jews, to keep alive and to perform their common heritage and legacy.
==See also== * [[Foreign relations of Morocco]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * {{cite news |url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1032255.html |first=Yoav |last=Stern |title=Morocco king's Jewish aide urges Israel to adopt Saudi peace plan |newspaper=[[Haaretz]] |date=29 October 2008 }}
==External links== * [http://en.qantara.de/webcom/show_article.php/_c-476/_nr-1404/i.html Interview with André Azoulay: "The Dialogue between the Cultures Is My Life's Work"]
{{Mohammed VI |state=collapsed}}

{{Infobox organization |name = Bangladesh Small and Cottage Industries Corporation |image = BSCIC, Chittagong Regional Office (03).jpg |image_border = |size = |alt = |caption = Chittagong regional office |map = |msize = |malt = |mcaption = |abbreviation = |motto = |formation = 1957 |extinction = |type = |status = |purpose = |headquarters = [[Dhaka]], [[Bangladesh]] |location = |coords = <!-- Coordinates of location using a coordinates template --> |region_served = Bangladesh |members = |language = Bengali |leader_title = |leader_name = |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.bscic.gov.bd/ Bangladesh Small and Cottage Industries Corporation] |remarks = }} '''Bangladesh Small and Cottage Industries Corporation (বিসিক)''' ('''BSCIC''') provides support services to small, rural, and cottage industry in [[Bangladesh]] in the small and cottage industries sector. It was created through an [[Act of Parliament]] in 1957 which was later amended in 1992. BSCIC has country-wide institution network to provide door step services for entrepreneurs. Head Office of BSCIC is located at 137-138, Motijheel, Dhaka, Bangladesh.<ref name=BSCICact>[http://www.parliamentofbangladesh.org/Legislation_New/legislation1990act57a.htm Transcript of The Bangladesh Small and Cottage Industries Corporation (Amendment) Act, 1990] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928061457/http://www.parliamentofbangladesh.org/Legislation_New/legislation1990act57a.htm |date=September 28, 2007 }}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Bangladesh_Small_and_Cottage_Industries_Corporation|title=Bangladesh Small and Cottage Industries Corporation - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|access-date=2016-09-18}}</ref>
== History == Bangladesh Small and Cottage Industries Corporation traces its origins to East Pakistan Small and Cottage Industries Corporation, which was established through the East Pakistan Small and Cottage Industries Corporation Act. 1957. The act was created by the Minister for Labour, Commerce and Industry [[Sheikh Mujibur Rahman]] of the [[United Front]] government of [[East Pakistan]]. After the Independence of Bangladesh it was made into BSCIC. In October 1973 BSCIC was split into Bangladesh Cottage Industries Corporation and Bangladesh Small Industries Corporation. In 1975 [[Bangladesh Handloom Board]] and [[Bangladesh Sericulture Board]] were separated from BSCIC.<ref name=":0" />
==Definition== * Small Industry (Manufacturing): Small Industry means an industry in which the value/replacement cost of durable resources other than land and factory buildings is in between (.05 to 15 million) taka and employment generation is not more than 50 persons. * Cottage Industry (Manufacturing): Cottage Industry means family an industry in which members are engaged part-time or full-time in production and service-oriented activities. * Medium Industry (Manufacturing): Medium Industry means an industry in which the value/replacement cost of durable resources other than land and factory buildings is between 15 million and 200 million taka and employment generation is not more than 150 persons .<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927090333/http://www.ciionline.org/services/112/Images/defsme.pdf Definition of Small Industries in Various Countries]</ref> [[Image:Print machine 5color.JPG|thumb|220px|One of Industrial unit established by Private Entrepreneur with the support services of BSCIC]]
==Functions== BSCIC provides medium and long term loans to small industries, either directly, or through consortium of [[commercial bank]]s. BSCIC also provides assistance in all other matters relating to development and expansion of small and cottage industries (SCI). The Bangladesh Small and Cottage Industry Corporation (BSCIC) is the official body which monitors the development of self-employment, cottage industries and small enterprises. It produces statistics on the types of enterprises, their activities and the number of people employed.<ref>[http://www.dial.prd.fr/dial_publications/PDF/Doc_travail/1997-13.PDF Monitoring Urban Poverty at the Bangladesh Bureau of Statistics] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061125124602/http://www.dial.prd.fr/dial_publications/PDF/Doc_travail/1997-13.PDF |date=November 25, 2006 }}</ref>
Its major functions are:<ref name=BSCICact/> * [[Promotion (marketing)|Promotion]] and registration of small and cottage industries * Conducting advisory and industrial promotion services including training of entrepreneurs * Skill development for [[artisans]] and [[Artisan|craftsmen]] * Creation of jobs for SCIs * Construction and development of industrial estates with necessary [[infrastructural]] facilities for SCI * Development of linkages between SCIs and large and medium-sized industries. * Online Service for registration of Industry, Application for Industrial plots, Application for Training facilities will be provide very soon.
==Current status== BSCIC has developed a total of 74 industrial estates throughout the country to foster the growth of SCIs in a balanced manner and also construction works for a number of estates including special type like Tannery, API (Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients) and Garments Park are under execution.<ref>BSCIC Document</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Footnotes== 1 BSCIC_ACT http://bdlaws.minlaw.gov.bd/pdf_part.php?act_name=&vol=&id=274
==External links== {{Commons category|Bangladesh Small and Cottage Industry Corporation}} * [http://www.bscic.gov.bd// The BSCIC Website] * {{cite book |last=Reza |first=Masud |year=2012 |chapter=Cottage Industry |chapter-url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Cottage_Industry |editor1-last=Islam |editor1-first=Sirajul |editor1-link=Sirajul Islam |editor2-last=Jamal |editor2-first=Ahmed A. |title=Banglapedia: National Encyclopedia of Bangladesh |edition=Second |publisher=[[Asiatic Society of Bangladesh]]}} * {{cite book |last=Rahman |first=AHM Habibur |year=2012 |chapter=Entrepreneurship |chapter-url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Entrepreneurship |editor1-last=Islam |editor1-first=Sirajul |editor1-link=Sirajul Islam |editor2-last=Jamal |editor2-first=Ahmed A. |title=Banglapedia: National Encyclopedia of Bangladesh |edition=Second |publisher=[[Asiatic Society of Bangladesh]]}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070103024226/http://www.un.int/bangladesh/gen/invest.htm Investment opportunities in Bangladesh] * [http://www.publicprivatedialogue.org/case_studies/Case%20Study%2001%20-%20Bangladesh%20-%20Craig.pdf Public-Private Dialogue Case Study: Bangladesh] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081004060529/http://www.newagebd.com/2005/jul/27/busi.html The ''New Age'' reports on BSCIC]

{{multiple issues| {{notability|Events|date=January 2013}} {{orphan|date=January 2013}} {{primary sources|date=January 2013}} }} '''Boutique Week''' is a bi-annual shopping event in New York, Boston, Los Angeles, Chicago, and Miami. Boutique Week was launched in October 2010 in New York, Boston, and Los Angeles with over 40 [[boutiques]] participating in each city.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.boutiqueweek.net |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-09-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100919143430/http://www.boutiqueweek.net/ |archivedate=2010-09-19 |df= }}</ref> Each of the participating boutiques offers their merchandise at a discount of at least 25% off during the selected week.
==support== Boutique Week is supported by local government in these cities as an effort to stimulate the economy and raise awareness for small local businesses.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.boutiqueweek.net/index.php?view%3Dpage%26pageId%3D3 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-09-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101023054400/http://boutiqueweek.net/index.php?view=page&pageId=3 |archivedate=2010-10-23 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://boldfacers.com/index.cfm?page%3Dhappenings |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-09-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708081449/http://boldfacers.com/index.cfm?page=happenings |archivedate=2011-07-08 |df= }}</ref>
Boutique Week also raises money for [[Nancy Lublin]]'s non-profit organisation [[Dress For Success (organization)|Dress for Success]], supplying women with [[interview suit]]s and resources they need for success in today's workforce.
==Founders== Boutique Week was founded in July 2010 by Polina Raygorodskaya and Olga Vidisheva.
Polina Raygorodskaya<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polinafashion.com|title=NYC Fashion PR, Marketing, Fashion Public Relations|website=www.polinafashion.com}}</ref> is the founder and president of Polina Fashion LLC. Formerly a top [[runway model]], Raygorodskaya earned a [[BS degree]] in [[Business Administration]] at [[Babson College]]. Her entrepreneurial endeavors have been recognized by [[Fox Business Channel]] and [[LegalZoom]]. In 2007, [[Business Week]] named her as one of the "Best 25 Entrepreneurs Under 25".<ref>http://www.businessweek.com/smallbiz/content/oct2007/sb20071019_394343_page_2.htm</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legalzoom.com/business-management/success-stories/hottest-young-entrepreneurs|title=The Hottest Young Entrepreneurs of 2008|date=1 December 2009|publisher=}}</ref>
Olga Vidisheva is currently pursuing a [[Masters degree]] in Business Administration at [[Harvard Business School]]. Most recently, she worked for [[Chanel]] in their 'Fashion' and 'Fragrance and Beauté' marketing divisions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nypost.com/pagesixmag/issues/20100914/Harvard+Goes+High+Fashion |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-09-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100918031704/http://www.nypost.com/pagesixmag/issues/20100914/Harvard%2BGoes%2BHigh%2BFashion |archivedate=2010-09-18 |df= }}</ref>
==Notes== <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using >ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100919143430/http://www.boutiqueweek.net/ Boutique Week website] * [http://www.dressforsuccess.org/ Dress for Success website]

{{Infobox person | name = Carl Roth II | image = Goya Forge.jpg | image_size = 220px | caption = [[Francisco Goya]]'s Forge | birth_date = 12 October 1753 | birth_place = [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]] | death_date = 30 November 1832 | death_place = [[Karlstad Municipality]], [[Värmland County]], [[Sweden]] | occupation = Ironworks owner and manager | spouse = Elisabeth Antonsson | children = [[Carl Reinhold Roth]] (1797) | parents = [[Carl Roth of Nedre Fösked|Carl Roth]], Agatha Romanians | residence = Nedre Fösked }}
'''Carl Roth II''' was a Swedish [[ironmaster]] who lived between the 17th and 18th centuries. He is best known for owning two [[ironworks]] in [[Karlstad Municipality]], [[Värmland County]], [[Sweden]]: Duvnäs (Duvenäs), and Nedre Fösked (Föske).
==Early life== [[File:Gustav III of Sweden at the Gustavianum in 1786.jpg|thumb|left|250px| 1792 drawing of Uppsala University by Louis [[Louis Jean Desprez]]]] Carl was born on October 12, 1753, in [[Stockholm]]. On June 26, 1764, at the age of 10, he enrolled at [[Uppsala University]] under [[Stockholms nation|Stockholm's Nation]]. After graduating in 1771, he moved with his parents to their estate at Duvnäs where he focused primarily on agriculture and working at the family's [[Mill (grinding)|mill]]. Carl was said to have a Godly and humble disposition and loved books above all else.
==Later life== Carl presumebly took over operations at Duvnäs upon his father's death in 1788. On December 12, 1794, at the age of 42 he married Elisabeth Antonsson at Molkoms Mill. She was the only daughter of the Värmland renowned [[ironmaster]], Judge Reinhold Antonsson. In 1795 he purchased Nedre Fösked from his brother, Benjamin, and captain Lars von Nackrej where all of his children were born. He worked as ironmaster of both Ironworks until 1817 when he sold them to the wholesaler Per Gustaf Geijer. He then rented a mill at Kjern (Tjärn) until 1830 when he purchased a home in [[Karlstad]]. Carl II died at the age of 80 on Friday the 30th of November, 1832 in Karlstad.
==References== {{reflist}} * Kristoffer Huldt, Översikt av Släkten Roth (Overview of House Roth) * Handlingar Rörande Släkten Roth (Documents Relating to House Roth) [http://www.ediffah.org/search/present.cgi?id=ediffah:kb:747645:1368601755&termlist=acc2008+80&boollist=&fieldlist=unitid&number=10&start=1&script=search.php Acc 2008/80] * [https://riksarkivet.se/sbl Svenskt Biografiskt Lexicon] (Swedish Biographical Lexicon)
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Roth, Carl, II}} [[Category:1753 births]] [[Category:1832 deaths]] [[Category:Swedish ironmasters]] [[Category:Swedish businesspeople]] [[Category:Uppsala University alumni]]

{{italictitle}} [[File:Comfort, v. XVI, no. 4, February 1904.jpg|thumb|Comfort, v. XVI, no. 4, February 1904]] '''''Comfort''''' was a mail order magazine published in [[Augusta, Maine]] from 1888 to 1942. Published by [[Guy Gannett Communications|Gannet & Morris]] and edited initially by William H. Gannet, ''Comfort'' was touted as "the key to happiness and success in over a million and quarter homes."<ref name="Mott">{{cite book|last1=Mott|first1=Frank Luther|title=A History of American Magazines, 1885-1905, Vol. 4|date=1957|publisher=The Belknap Press of the Harvard University Press|location=Cambridge, MA|page=365-366}}</ref>
In 1888, William H. Gannet created ''Comfort'' primarily as a means to advertise his [[patent medicine]], Giant Oxien, a variant of [[Moxie|The Moxie Nerve Food]].<ref name="Sayward">{{cite journal|last1=Sayward|first1=Dorothy Steward|title=Comfort Magazine, 1888-1942: A History and Critical Study|journal=University of Maine Bulletin|date=January 1960|volume=62|issue=13|page=7-8}}</ref> ''Comfort''{{'}}s circulation increased from 13,000, in 1888, to 1.3 million, in 1894, which made ''Comfort'' the first publication in America to reach a circulation of 1 million.<ref name="Mott"/> In order to handle this increase in circulation, Gannet purchased a new rotary color convertible web-fed press, which was one of the first of its kind in the country.<ref name="Weber">{{cite journal|last1=Weber|first1=Clara Carter|title=Comfort Magazine|journal=Colby Library Quarterly|date=November 1955|volume=4|issue=4|page=81|url=http://digitalcommons.colby.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1474&context=cq|accessdate=April 11, 2016}}</ref>
The increase in ''Comfort''{{'}}s circulation was primarily due to its use of premiums to generate subscriptions. Premiums, essentially rewards like sewing machines or clothing, were given to people who submitted "clubs" or lists of new subscribers. As [[Frank Luther Mott]] notes in his book, ''A History of American Magazines'', the use of the "'club' device made the solicitor virtually a local subscription agent for the periodical."<ref name="Mott2">{{cite book|last1=Mott|first1=Frank Luther|title=A History of American Magazines, 1885-1905, Vol. 4|date=1957|publisher=The Belknap Press of the Harvard University Press|location=Cambridge, MA|page=17-18}}</ref> Most of the time, publishers of mail-order magazines did not depend on the collection of subscription fees and instead generated income by selling their subscription lists to advertisers.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Zuckerman|first1=Mary Ellen|title=A History of Popular Women's Magazines in the United States, 1792-1995|date=1998|publisher=Greenwood Press|location=Westport, CT|page=9}}</ref>
The practice of not collecting subscriptions fees went against the [[United States Post Office Department|United States Post Office Department's]] criteria that required publications to maintain "a legitimate list of subscribers" in order to take advantage of the low second-class mailing rate of one-cent per pound.<ref name="USPS">{{cite web|last1=United States Postal Service|title=Postal Rates for Periodicals: A Narrative History|url=https://about.usps.com/who-we-are/postal-history/periodicals-postage-history.htm|website=About|accessdate=April 19, 2016}}</ref> In 1907, as a way to curb further abuse of the second-class postal rate, the US Post Office mandated that all subscription fees must be paid in advance. Many mail-order magazines could not meet this requirement and folded. The publishers of ''Comfort'', who were more firm about collecting payment than other mail-order magazine publishers, lowered ''Comfort''{{'}}s price to 15 cents a year in order to meet with the new regulations.<ref name="Mott3">{{cite book|last1=Mott|first1=Frank Luther|title=A History of American Magazines, 1885-1905, Vol. 4|date=1957|publisher=The Belknap Press of the Harvard University Press|location=Cambridge, MA|page=365}}</ref>
To prevent mail-order magazines from becoming little more than advertisement catalogs, the US Post Office also required mail-order magazines provide readers with "information of a public character, or devoted to literature, the sciences, arts, or some special industry."<ref name="USPS" /> This regulation may explain why ''Comfort'' claimed on its front page to be "devoted to art, literature, science, and the home circle."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://digital.library.villanova.edu/Item/vudl:395358 |title=Comfort, v. XX, no. 1, November 1907|website= Digital Library @ Villanova University|accessdate=April 21, 2016}}</ref> In addition to the columns of advertisements, ''Comfort'' provided readers with various articles geared to meet the needs and interests of every member of the rural, American family. With articles like "In & Around the Home,"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://digital.library.villanova.edu/Item/vudl:378294 |title=Comfort, v. XVI, no. 4, February 1904|website= Digital Library @ Villanova University|accessdate=April 21, 2016|page= 6}}</ref> "Comfort Sisters' Recipes,"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://digital.library.villanova.edu/Item/vudl:303790 |title=Comfort, v. XXXI, no. 6, April 1919|website=Digital Library @ Villanova University|accessdate=April 21, 2016|page= 5}}</ref> and "The Pretty Girls' Club,"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://digital.library.villanova.edu/Item/vudl:357396 |title=Comfort, v. XXXIII, no. 10, August 1921|website= Digital Library @ Villanova University.|accessdate=April 21, 2016|page= 14}}</ref> much of ''Comfort'' was dominated by content for women, which offered advice and information on cooking, sewing, health, and beauty. ''Comfort'' also printed articles aimed at men, although not as many, such as "The Modern Farmer" and "Automobile and Gas Engine Helps."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://digital.library.villanova.edu/Item/vudl:378505 |title=Comfort, v. XXIX, no. 6, April 1907|website= Digital Library @ Villanova University|accessdate=April 21, 2016|page= 13, 18}}</ref> For children, ''Comfort'' occasionally published puzzles, activities, and comics.
Another prominent feature of ''Comfort'' was its short and serialized fiction. When ''Comfort'' was first published, much of the fiction was written by William H. Gannet as a means to further plug Giant Oxien and other products displayed in the magazine's advertisements. From roughly September 1892 to April 1902, ''Comfort'' offered prizes to readers who submitted works of fiction for publication. In later years, ''Comfort'' went on to publish fiction written by more legitimate and well known authors such as [[Augusta Jane Evans]], [[Sarah Elizabeth Forbush Downs|Mrs. Georgie Sheldon]], [[Horatio Alger Jr.]], [[Charles Felton Pidgin]], and [[L. M. Montgomery]]. The fiction published in ''Comfort'' was usually highly moral and typically fell into three genres: [[List of genres#Adventure|Adventure]], [[List of genres#Mystery|Mystery]], or [[List of Genres#Romance|Sentimental Romance]].<ref name="Sayward 2">{{cite journal|last1=Sayward|first1=Dorothy Steward|title=Comfort Magazine, 1888-1942: A History and Critical Study|journal=University of Maine Bulletin|date=January 1960|volume=62|issue=13|page=58-61}}</ref> Additionally, ''Comfort'' printed stories for children. The Cubby Bear stories, written by Lena B. Ellingwood and illustrated by [[Harrison Cady]], were the most regular children's fiction published in ''Comfort''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://digital.library.villanova.edu/Item/vudl:303790 |title=Comfort, v. XXXI, no. 6, April 1919|website= Digital Library @ Villanova University|accessdate=April 21, 2016|page= 8}}</ref>
In 1940, ''Comfort'' was sold to the Needlecraft Publishing Corporation. Needlecraft Publishing continued to publish ''Comfort'' for two years until it was combined with ''Needlecraft'' magazine, which ceased to be published soon after.<ref name="Mott3" />
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [https://digital.library.villanova.edu/Item/vudl:304358 Digitized issues of Comfort at the Digital Library@Villanova University]

revision.comment: /* Exam Structure */
revision.text:
The '''Common Final Examination (CFE)''' is the last [[Test (assessment)|examination]] [[Chartered Professional Accountant|CPA Students]] took in pursuit of the Chartered Professional Accountant (CPA) designation in Canada. The 3-day CFE is also reputed to be among the world's most challenging professional exams where students are required to use an integrative business thinking model to obtain the designation. Previously known as the Uniform Evaluation (UFE), the UFE has been discontinued following the unification of the three accounting designations (CA, CMA, CGA) in [[Canada]] and [[Bermuda]] in June 2015.
Administered nationally by [[CPA Canada]], and conducted regionally by the provincial/regional orders, the CFE is written over the course of three sequential days and is the culmination of years of study in [[financial accounting]], [[management accounting]], [[corporate finance]], [[performance management]], [[taxation]] and other business-related university courses. Writing the CFE requires successful completion of preliminary education requirements including CPA preparatory courses and Professional Education Program (PEP). Upon passing the CFE and 30 months of approved practical experiences, the candidate will become a [[Chartered Professional Accountant]]<ref>{{cite web |title=The new Chartered Professional Accountant (CPA) certification program: Overview |url=https://www.cpacanada.ca/en/become-a-cpa/why-become-a-cpa/the-cpa-certification-program/the-cpa-certification-program-overview |website=CPA Canada |publisher=CPA Canada |accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref>.
The Common Final Exam is typically offered once per year in September (Fall). Sometimes, it may be offered twice a year in Spring and Fall (such as May and September 2016). The upcoming CFE dates are: September 11 - September 13, 2019. Two CFEs are scheduled for 2020, between May 26 - May 29 and September 9 - September 11, 2020<ref>{{cite web |title=Common Final Examination |url=https://www.cpacanada.ca/en/become-a-cpa/cpa-certification-program-evaluation/cpa-certification-capstone-1-cfe-cases |website=CPA Canada |publisher=CPA Canada |accessdate=9 November 2018}}</ref>.
== CPA Competency Map == ===Technical Competency=== # [[Financial Accounting|Financial Reporting]] # [[Management Accounting]] # [[Strategic Management|Strategy & Governance]] # [[Audit|Audit & Assurance]] # [[Finance|Corporate Finance]] # [[Taxation in Canada|Taxation]]
===Enabling Competency=== # [[Professionalism]] # [[Business Ethics|Ethical Behaviour]] # [[Communication|Written & Oral Communications]] # [[Leadership]] # [[Problem Solving]] # [[Decision Making]]
Old UFE Competency Map: # [[Corporate governance|Governance]], [[Strategy]], & [[Risk Management]] # [[Financial statements|Performance Measurement and Reporting]] # [[Assurance services|Assurance]] # [[Finance]] # [[Management accounting|Management Decision-Making]] # [[Taxation]] # [[Business ethics|Pervasive Qualities]] (Including both business and [[professional ethics]] and other overarching considerations such as [[fraud]] awareness)
== Exam Structure ==
Students must demonstrate the depth and breadth of their abilities according to the CPA Competency Map. Students answer questions which are presented in the form of business cases that include a combination of both explicit and implicit requirements for each case's "users", followed by a list of exhibits that provide case facts from which observations, suggestions and conclusions are derived. Common scenarios include providing advice on how to conduct an audit, advising a client on the pros and cons of investing funds in a given business venture, and providing support to an organization as an internal accountant or auditor.
All students must demonstrate "depth" in financial reporting or management accounting for the CFE, and one of the elective areas. Students should also demonstrate "breadth" in all 6 competency areas.
The 3-day exam consisted of case based simulations<ref>{{cite web |title=How each day of the CFE works |url=http://www.cfeblog.ca/2016/01/22/how-each-day-of-the-cfe-works/ |website=CFE Blog |publisher=CFE Blog |accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref>: * Day 1: candidates will have 4 hours to write a case in relation to the Capstone 1 group project. Candidates will be assessed on enabling competencies such as communications skills and professionalism, as well as some technical competencies.
* Day 2: students would choose an elective "depth" area from 4 competency areas - Performance Management, Finance, Assurance or Taxation. Day 2 will last 5 hours in length and students must be "Competent" in the chosen elective area as well as either Financial Reporting or Management Accounting. Note that students wishing to pursue a Public Accounting Licence must have passed Assurance and Taxation from their prior PEP modules and show depth in both Financial Reporting and Assurance on the CFE <ref>{{cite web |title=Elective Depth Role |url=https://www.cpaontario.ca/become-a-cpa/complete-your-designation/cpa-pep-cfe |website=CPA Ontario |publisher=CPA Ontario |accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Become a Licensed Public Accountant (LPA) |url=https://www.cpaontario.ca/become-a-cpa/why-cpa/program-info/public-accountant-licence |website=Public Accountant Licence |publisher=CPA Ontario |accessdate=2 December 2018}}</ref>.
* Day 3: multiple (usually 3) multi-competency cases would be provided within a time frame of 4 hours aimed to evaluate the student's "breadth" in the competency map. A minimum "Reaching Competent (RC)" grade must be achieved for every single competency (all 6 areas).
===Evaluation Criteria=== All CPA cases are evaluated based on "Competency Ratings". They are: * '''Not Addressed (NA)''': Candidate has not addressed the Assessment Opportunity. * '''Not Competent (NC)''': Candidate has addressed the Assessment Opportunity, but the analysis is incorrect or not related to the issue. * '''Reaching Competent (RC)''': RCs and Cs are both counted towards "Breadth" test for day 3. RC candidates demonstrate more proficiency and understanding than NC, but not at the Competent level. * '''Competent (C)''': the amount of Cs are used for the "depth" test on day 2. Competent candidates demonstrate the required competency levels as expected by a CPA. * '''Competent with Distinction (CD)''': Candidates are not expected to achieve this high level of competency. CDs are essentially Cs in terms of exam grading.
===Pass and Fail Decision=== The evaluation decision is separate into day 1 and day 2 with day 3. A student must pass all 3 days in order to "pass the CFE". However, Day 1 is marked separately and Day 2 & 3 are marked together. Therefore, a candidate can pass Day 1 and fail Day 2 & 3 and vice versa.<ref>{{cite web |title=Common Final Examination (CFE) Enrolment FAQs |url=https://www.cpaontario.ca/become-a-cpa/complete-your-designation/cpa-pep-cfe/cpa-common-final-examination/common-final-examination-enrolment-faq |website=CPA Ontario |publisher=CPA Ontario |accessdate=2 December 2018}}</ref> *If a student passes Day 1 and fails Days 2 & 3, the student has to write Days 2 & 3 on their next attempt. *If a student fails Day 1 and passes Days 2 & 3, the student has to write Day 1 on their next attempt (the Capstone 1 case may be different and the student will need to ensure they are comfortable with the new Capstone 1 case). *If the student fails all three days, they must rewrite all three days.
A candidate may attempt the Common Final Examination 3 times maximum. A student will be deregistered after their third unsuccessful attempt at either Core 1, Core 2, Capstone 1, Capstone 2 or the CFE. A student may not be admitted back to CPA or re-registered except in extraordinary circumstances.<ref>{{cite web |title=Common Final Examination - Frequently Asked Questions |url=https://www.cpaontario.ca/become-a-cpa/complete-your-designation/cpa-pep-cfe/cfe-results-faqs |website=CFE Results FAQs |publisher=CPA Ontario |accessdate=2 December 2018}}</ref>
== Pass Rates==
The exam is administered once per year during September and approximately 5,500 students attempt the exam each year. National pass rates for 2003 to 2008 have been 65.5%,<ref>Institute of Chartered Accountants in Canada and Bermuda: "Uniform Evaluation Report 2003", page 12. The Canadian Institute of Chartered Accountants, 2004.</ref> 74.5%,<ref>Institute of Chartered Accountants in Canada and Bermuda: "Uniform Evaluation Report 2004", page 12. The Canadian Institute of Chartered Accountants, 2005.</ref> 74.0%,<ref>Institute of Chartered Accountants in Canada and Bermuda: "Uniform Evaluation Report 2005", page 12. The Canadian Institute of Chartered Accountants, 2006.</ref> 79.3%,<ref>Institute of Chartered Accountants in Canada and Bermuda: "Uniform Evaluation Report 2006", page 12. The Canadian Institute of Chartered Accountants, 2007.</ref> 74.6%,<ref>Institute of Chartered Accountants in Canada and Bermuda: "Uniform Evaluation Report 2007", page 12. The Canadian Institute of Chartered Accountants, 2008.</ref> and 71.7%<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.casb.com/index.php?catid=65|title=CA School of Business UFE Statistics|accessdate=2008-12-09}}</ref> respectively. Exam results are released in late November following each September sitting of the UFE.
Beginning with the September 2009 UFE, the Board of Evaluators no longer releases statistics on pass rates.
The CFE Board of Evaluators began releasing statistics on pass rates along with Board Reports on candidate performance. The following are the first attempts of CFE Pass Rates for CFE<ref>{{cite web |title=CPA certification program: Examination performance rates |url=https://www.cpacanada.ca/en/become-a-cpa/cpa-certification-program-evaluation/cpa-examination-performance-rates |website=CPA Canada |publisher=CPA Canada |accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref>: * 2017 September CFE 77.6% * 2016 September CFE 76.8% * 2016 May CFE 68.7% * 2015 September CFE 82.9%
== Exam Entry Method ==
Since 2005, students have been able to type in their responses on laptop computers secured with Securexam (CA) lockdown software in all regions of Canada.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cica.ca/becoming-a-ca/the-ufe/computers-in-the-ufe/index.aspx|title=Computers in the UFE|accessdate=2008-12-25}}</ref> Use of computer is no longer voluntary. It became a requirement to use a computer starting with the 2009 UFE.
== CFE Honour Roll & Gold Medal == Every CFE, the Board would release the Honour Roll recipients along with the CFE results. The CFE honour roll members consists of the nation's top 1% performers on the exam and recognizes performance in the exam that demonstrated academic excellence and exceptional abilities. The Honour Roll of 68 candidates is determined as the top 1% of the first-time writers that wrote all three days.<ref>{{cite web |title=Common Final Examination (CFE) honour roll |url=https://www.cpacanada.ca/en/become-a-cpa/cpa-certification-program-evaluation/common-final-examination-honour-roll |website=CPA Canada |publisher=CPA Canada |accessdate=2 December 2018}}</ref> Among the honour roll members, a national Gold Medal (highest standing in Canada) is selected, along with 3 provincial gold medalists (top performers in their respective CPA representations). The CPA Governor General's Gold Medal (National Gold Medal) is awarded to 1 individual for a cash prize of $5,000. While each regional Gold Medalist receives a cash price of $2,500 each.
=== Successful Candidates === '''2018:''' Ontario - https://www.cpaontario.ca/cfe2018/cfe-exam-results
== References == {{reflist}}

revision.comment: typo
revision.text:
A '''corporate university''' is any educational entity that is a strategic tool designed to assist its parent organization in achieving its goals by conducting activities that foster individual and organizational learning and knowledge.<ref name="Allen">{{cite book|last=Allen|first=Mark|title=The Corporate University Handbook|publisher=AMACOM Div American Mgmt Assn|date=2002|pages=9|isbn=978-0-8144-0711-0}}</ref> Corporate universities (CU) are a growing trend in [[corporation]]s. In 1993, corporate universities existed in only 400 companies. By 2001, this number had increased to 2,000, including [[The Walt Disney Company|Walt Disney]], [[Boeing]], and [[Motorola]].<ref name="Hearn">{{cite web|url=http://www.newfoundations.com/OrgTheory/Hearn721.html|title=Education in the Workplace: An Examination of Corporate University Models |last=Hearn|first=Denise R.|date=2002-05-10|accessdate=2009-01-27}}</ref>
The 'corporate university' also refers to public universities which have developed, or have been forced by states to develop, corporate style behaviour<ref> Marginson and Considine, 2000, https://www.amazon.com/Enterprise-University-Governance-Reinvention-Australia/dp/052179448X/ref=sr_1_5?ie=UTF8&qid=1528155796&sr=8-5&keywords=simon+marginson</ref>.
In most cases, corporate universities are not [[University|universities]] in the strict sense of the word. The traditional university is an educational institution which grants both [[undergraduate]] and [[postgraduate]] degrees in a variety of subjects, as well as conducting original scientific research. In contrast, a corporate university typically limits scope to providing job-specific, indeed company-specific, training for the managerial personnel of the parent corporation. Corporate universities are most commonly found in the [[United States]], a nation which has no official legal definition of the term "university". Perhaps the best known corporate university is the [[Hamburger University]] operated by [[McDonald's Corporation]] in [[Chicago]].
==Typical goals of a corporate university== Corporate universities are set up for a variety of reasons, but most organizations have the same basic needs. These are to:<ref name="Hearn"/> *Bring a common culture, loyalty, and belonging to a company *Get the most out of the investment in education *Organize training *Remain competitive in today's economy *Retain employees *Start and support change in the organization
CUs offer valuable training and education to employees, but they also help organizations retain and promote key employees. Although a CU may sound attractive, there is a lot of work that goes into the planning and implementation of such a project.
==Curriculum== [[J.P. Morgan]] and Co. is an example of a company with an organized curriculum.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dallas.bizjournals.com/dallas/stories/2003/07/28/focus2.html?page=1|title=Corporate university approach taking hold|last=Tanner|first=Lisa|date=2003-07-25|publisher=Dallas Business Journal|accessdate=2009-01-27}}</ref> They have three different types of courses: Business specific courses, organizational learning and communication classes, and management and executive training. What your company decides to offer will depend on your needs (such as sales training, marketing, or soft skills) and your company's business (like manufacturing, consulting, or technology).
Most CUs offer a blended curriculum of online and in person classes. Some organizations offer courses during the workday while other offer them at varying times. Courses can be short workshops or longer, more traditional courses.
Unlike traditional universities, CUs demand a return on their investment. There must be concrete evidence that the classroom is delivering results. Many CUs provide hands-on and team learning as a more effective alternative to lecture-based courses, but all CUs agree that what is learned in the classroom should be directly applicable to the work environment.
==Implementation== Although a CU may sound attractive, there is a lot of work that goes into the planning and implementation of such a project such as complex logistics, resource optimization and careful budgeting.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/training-roi-walmart-success-stéphane-pineau/|title=Training ROI- the Walmart success|last=Pineau|first=Stephane|date=2016-12-07|publisher=LinkedIn}}</ref> Indeed, corporate universities tend to be cost centers with dedicated training facilities servicing an often global workforce through a dedicated curriculum. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.economist.com/news/business/21651217-more-firms-have-set-up-their-own-corporate-universities-they-have-become-less-willing-pay|title=Keeping it on the company campus|date=2015-05-15|publisher=The Economist|accessdate=2018-02-14}}</ref> To manage this complexity, specific [[Enterprise resource planning]] systems have been developed for Corporate Universities, such as a [[Training management system]]. Other systems such as accounting systems and different types of [[Educational Technology| learning technologies]] can be used together.
==See also== *[[Apple University]] *[[Hamburger University]] *[[Disney University]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==References== {{Refbegin}} *{{cite book|last=Renaud-Coulon|first=Annick|title=Corporate Universities, a lever of Corporate Responsibility|publisher=GlobalCCU Publisher|date=2008|isbn=978-2-9531667-0-5}} *{{cite book|last=Paton|first=Rob |author2=Geoff Peters |author3=John Storey |author4=Scott Taylor|title=Handbook of Corporate University Development: Managing Strategic Learning Initiatives in Public and Private Domains|publisher=Gower Publishing, Ltd.|date=2005|isbn=978-0-566-08583-3}} {{Refend}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Cleanup|date=July 2013|reason=English quality}} {{Infobox person |name = Cyril Bourlon de Rouvre |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = Bourlon de Rouvre |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1945|12|19|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Boulogne-Billancourt]], France |death_date = |death_place = |body_discovered = |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = [[France|French]] |nationality = [[France|French]] |ethnicity = |citizenship = [[France|French]] |other_names = |known_for = Team principal [[Equipe Ligier|Ligier]] |education = [[Aerospace engineer]] |alma_mater = [[Lycée Janson-de-Sailly]]
[[Institut polytechnique des sciences avancées]] |employer = |occupation = [[Businessman]] and [[politician]] |years_active = |home_town = |title = |salary = |networth = |height = |weight = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |party = |opponents = |boards = |religion = |spouse = |partner = |children = |parents = |relations = |callsign = |signature = |website = |footnotes = }} '''Cyril Hubert Marie Bourlon de Rouvre''' is a [[France|French]] [[businessman]] and [[politician]], born 19 December 1945 at [[Boulogne-Billancourt]]. == Biography == === Education and early career === Son of Évrard Bourlon de Rouvre, an industrialist, and his wife Claude Genty, Cyril Bourlon de Rouvre is the heir of sugar refineries and the landed property of his great-grandfather, Charles Bourlon de Rouvre (1850-1924), himself stepson of one of the richest men at the end of the 19th century, Gustave Lebaudy. After studies at the ''collège Maspero'' in [[Paris]], then at the ''collège Saint-Martin de France'' in [[Pontoise]], the [[The Oratory School|Oratory School]] in [[Reading, Berkshire|Reading]], the ''Collège Saint-Jean'' in [[Fribourg]] and at the ''[[Lycée Janson-de-Sailly]]'',[http://www.grandprix.com/gpe/cref-dercyr.html PEOPLE: CYRIL BOURLON DE ROUVRE] Cyril Bourlon de Rouvre studied [[electrical engineering]] at ''[[Jussieu Campus|Jussieu]]'' before graduating as an [[aerospace engineer]] at the ''[[Institut polytechnique des sciences avancées]]''. He first worked at ''[[Électricité de France]]'' before serving his [[conscription]] and started his career as a sales engineer at the Elliot Automation company (1966-1968) before being Director of export of the Sucre Union company (1971-1973). He was business manager of the sales support department of the Lara audiovisual company (1973), then commercial agent in the audiovisual (1974-1975) and associate director at the Auto Racing company (1977). === A young and dynamic business leader === In 1979, upon the death of his father (who was murdered by his valet), he inherited large real estate holdings, a sugar refinery and 28 companies. He became [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of ''Financière Robur et de Cofragec'' (1982-1992),{{fr icon}} [http://www.liberation.fr/france/0101180993-la-drole-de-faillite-de-cyril-de-rouvre-ancien-patron-de-ligier La drôle de faillite de Cyril de Rouvre, ancien patron de Ligier] ''Coficine'' (1984-1992) and many other companies. He modernized the sugar factory and his inheritance prospered, taking, in 1981, control of the holding Fraissinet, owner of the business airline Transair. In 1987, he started a new career in film distribution by acquiring, from the producer [[Robert Dorfmann]],{{fr icon}} [http://www.lexpress.fr/informations/les-millions-de-cyril_596731.html Les millions de Cyril] by one of its companies, the ''Financière Robur'', Cofragec company with its catalog of 650 films including ''[[La Grande Vadrouille]]'' or ''[[La Vache et le Prisonnier]]''. He produced movies including ''[[The Bengali Night|La Nuit bengali]]'' (1988) of [[Nicolas Klotz]], ''Les Deux Fragonard'' (1989) of Philippe Le Guay, and ''[[La Peste]]'' (1992) of [[Luis Puenzo]]. He also invested in real estate, including a hotel in [[Tahiti]]. Passionate about cars and racing, he rallied with [[Thierry Sabine]], including Abidjan-Nice driving a [[Range Rover]]. === Political life in Haute-Marne and investment in Formula 1 === In 1989, he started a political career in ''[[Haute-Marne]]'', a department where which his grandfather Charles de Rouvre was a deputy during the [[French Third Republic|Third Republic]]. He was elected mayor of [[Chaumont, Haute-Marne|Chaumont]], as an independent (classified as [[miscellaneous right]]) against the centrist senator and mayor Georges Berchet, and regional councilor for the [[Champagne-Ardenne]] [[Region of France|region]] (1992-1998). He takes his team, as an alderman, a man of 25 years, [[Luc Chatel]], becoming in fact the first « political godfather ». Owner of the [[Formula 1|Formula 1 team]] [[Automobiles Gonfaronnaises Sportives|AGS]] from March 1989 to 1991, he swallowed $ 18 million and began selling activities of his group, about 70 companies: First Transair, then the sugar factory, sold to the ''Compagnie de Navigation Mixte'', and in 1992, the catalog of movies, lent to [[UGC (cinema operator)|UGC]] in the form of a merger. In 1991, he gives AGS the Italians Gabriele Rafanelli and Patrizio Cantu. In 1992, Cyril de Rouvre bought the [[Formula 1|Formula 1 team]] [[Equipe Ligier|Ligier]] for an estimated price of 200 million of francs. With its new owner, the team started to again be competitive - the [[1993 Formula One season|1993 season]] was a success, with a 5th place in the constructor's championship (the team's best result since 1986). But the involvement of Cyril de Rouvre lasted only one season because of legal troubles. === The legal troubles and the decline === The 14 December 1993, the judge [[Eva Joly]][http://www.liberation.fr/economie/0101125375-cyril-de-rouvre Cyril de Rouvre] incarcerated him at the [[Fleury-Mérogis Prison]], as part of a complaint for fraud filed by the leaders of UGC, Guy Verrecchia and Alain Sussfeld, following the takeover in June 1992 the company Cofragec. This company has been emptied of its assets, leaving a liability estimated at 172.6 million francs. Cyril de Rouvre had promised to repay this sum at the end of 1992 but at that time, he still had 100 million. On 5 May 1993, leaders of UGC have filed a complaint against him. He spent two months in prison. In early 1994, he sold [[Equipe Ligier|Ligier]] to [[Flavio Briatore]]. He lost the mayoralty of Chaumont at the [[French municipal elections, 1995|French municipal elections of 1995]]. In 1996, a judicial investigation was opened against him at the ''Tribunal de grande instance'' of Chaumont. He appeared before the Criminal Court of this city in September 1999 for tax evasion. Knowing that the prosecution had requested a sentence of three years imprisonment and a 20-year ban on company management, he was sentenced on 19 December 1999, his birthday, to a [[suspended sentence]] of 18 months imprisonment' a ban from managing a company for 3 years, and a large fine. == Bibliography == * ''[[Who's Who in France]]'', 2002-2003, [[Levallois-Perret]], Jacques Lafitte Editions, 2002, p. 1648 == References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bourlon de Rouvre, Cyril}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Boulogne-Billancourt]] [[Category:Institut Polytechnique des Sciences Avancées alumni]] [[Category:French businesspeople]] [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:Formula One people]] [[Category:Formula One team owners]]

{{Infobox Newspaper | name = Diagnostic and Interventional Cardiology | image = | caption = | type = [[business]] [[magazine]] | format = Paper and online magazine | foundation = 1961 | ceased publication = | price = | owners = Scranton Gillette Communications | editor = | founder = | language = [[English language|English]] | political = | circulation = 26, 242 | headquarters = [[Arlington Heights, Illinois]], USA | ISSN = 1551-6091 | website = [http://www.dicardiology.com Diagnostic and Interventional Cardiology] }}
'''''Diagnostic and Interventional Cardiology''''' is a trade magazine catering to [[cardiologist]]s and [[cath lab]]s.
==History and profile== ''Diagnostic and Interventional Cardiology'' was launched by Chilton Publishing in [[Philadelphia]] in 1961.<ref name="aus">{{cite news|title=About Us|url=http://www.dicardiology.com/about-us|accessdate=19 February 2016|work=Diagnostic and Interventional Cardiology}}</ref> In 1975 it was sold to Reilly Communications Group.<ref name="aus"/> The magazine is owned by Scranton Gillette Communications.<ref name=itn>{{cite news|title=Imaging Technology News, Diagnostic and Interventional Cardiology Capture Silver, Bronze ASHPE 2013 Awards|url=http://www.itnonline.com/article/imaging-technology-news-diagnostic-and-interventional-cardiology-capture-silver-bronze-ashpe|accessdate=19 June 2015|work=Imaging Technology News|date=6 May 2013}}</ref> Its focus is on [[interventional cardiology]], a branch of cardiology that uses catheter-based treatment to deal with structural heart disease. The magazine provides information about developments in this field<ref name="Columbia University Dept. of Medicine: Latest News">{{cite web|title=Columbia University Department of Medicine|url=http://www.columbiamedicine.org/about/news.shtml|publisher=Columbia Medicine|accessdate=26 August 2013}}</ref> and is a notable publication within the healthcare industry.<ref name='FluoroPharma CEO Provides Shareholders With a "State of the Union" Communication'>{{cite web|title=FluoroPharma CEO Provides Shareholders With a "State of the Union" Communication|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/fluoropharma-ceo-provides-shareholders-with-a-state-of-the-union-communication-2013-07-29|publisher=Marketwired via COMTEX|accessdate=26 August 2013}}</ref><ref name="Diagnostic and Interventional Cardiology Recognized by ASHPE">{{cite web|title=2013 Awards Competition List of Winners|url=http://www.ashpe.org/pdf/2013-winners.pdf|publisher=American Society of Healthcare Publication Editors|accessdate=16 July 2013}}</ref><ref name="What is needed for effective CDS software?">{{cite web|title=What is needed for effective CDS software?|url=http://www.emergecds.com/2013/03/|work=Emerge Clinical Decision Solutions|accessdate=26 August 2013}}</ref> The magazine was the recipient of American Society of Healthcare Publication Editors award in 2013.<ref name=itn/>
The magazine had 26,242 subscribers to its print edition in July 2013. Melinda Taschetta-Millane is its editorial director.
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.dicardiology.com Diagnostic and Interventional Cardiology] * [http://scrantongillette.com Scranton Gillette website]

{{Orphan|date=December 2012}}
'''Direct Debit Dividend Contributions''' also known as '''3DC''' are payments made towards [[stockholder|shareholders]] for [[stock|shares]] which have been issued on credit.
Issuing stock on credit is considered appropriate when a [[Stakeholder (corporate)|Stakeholder]] (such as company's founder or other key person) wishes to retain involvement in a business but is unable to raise the capital required to pay for stock. In such circumstances the company's shareholders may agree to issue the desired level of stock against a plan where shares must be paid for through direct debit dividend contributions. '''3DC''' differs from [[Stock options]] in that the recipient is awarded shareholder status from the moment the 3DC arrangement is agreed.
'''3DC''' is often regarded as a reward for efforts achieved (usually for the groundwork required in setting up a new business). It also serves as an incentive to ensure future performance of the company's stock.
==See also== *[[Direct debit]] *[[Authorised capital]] *[[Share capital]]
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100403060956/http://www.companieshouse.gov.uk/about/gbhtml/gba6.shtml Detailed break down] from [[Companies House]]
[[Category:Corporate law]]
{{finance-stub}}

revision.comment: added Christen Clifford
revision.text:
{{Infobox theatre | name = Dixon Place | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | image_map = | map_caption = | pushpin_map = | pushpin_map_caption= | address = 161A [[Chrystie Street]] | city = [[New York City]] | country = [[United States]] | designation = | coordinates = {{coord|40.720428|-73.992681|type:landmark_region:US-NY|display=inline,title}} | architect = | owner = | tenant = | operator = | capacity = 130 | type = [[Off-Off-Broadway]] | opened = 1986 | reopened = | yearsactive = | rebuilt = | closed = | demolished = | othernames = | production = | currentuse = | website = {{URL|http://www.dixonplace.org}} }}
'''Dixon Place''' is a theater organization located in [[New York City]] dedicated to the development of works-in-progress from a broad range of performers and artists. It exists to serve the creative needs of artists—emerging, mid-career and established—who are creating new work in theater, dance, music, literature, puppetry, performance, [[variety show|variety]] and visual arts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nyc-arts.org/organizations/31/dixon-place|title=Dixon Place|work=NYC-ARTS}}</ref>
Many well-known artists, including [[Ivy Baldwin]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americandance.org/performance/archived-performances/ivy-baldwin-dance/|title=Ivy Baldwin Dance - American Dance Institute|work=americandance.org}}</ref> [[Blue Man Group]], [[Laura Peterson]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/LauraPetersonChoreography/info?tab=page_info|title=Laura Peterson Choreography|work=Facebook}}</ref> [[Monica Bill Barnes]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://monicabillbarnes.com/events/events_past.html|title=Monica Bill Barnes + Company|work=monicabillbarnes.com}}</ref> [[John Leguizamo]], [[Lisa Kron]], [[David Cale]], [[Jane Comfort]], [[Risa Jaroslow]], [[Penny Arcade]], [[Katy Pyle]], [[Peggy Shaw]], [[Douglas Dunn]], [[Deb Margolin]] and [[Reno]], began their careers at Dixon Place.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mas.org/dixon-place-a-place-that-matters/|title=Dixon Place, A Place that Matters – The Municipal Art Society of New York|work=mas.org}}</ref>
Dixon Place offers 14 shows a week, 7–8 commissions a year, and more than 20 different programs across artistic disciplines, featuring work by more than 1,500 emerging and established artists each year. All artists presenting work in Dixon Place’s main-stage programs receive compensation, from work-in-progress showings to artists-in-residence and commissioned artists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dixonplace.org/about-us/mission/|title=mission/history|work=dixonplace.org}}</ref>
==History==
Dixon Place was founded in 1985 by Artistic Director Ellie Covan. After starting Dixon Place as a salon in her Paris apartment in the summer of 1985, Covan re-launched the endeavor in her East Village living room the following year. Her apartment was half of a storefront; she set up folding chairs for audiences and sold drinks and snacks to defray her expenses.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/01/09/theater/theater-dixon-place-a-real-home-for-theater-may-be-the-last-of-a-breed.html|title=THEATER - Dixon Place, a Real Home for Theater, May Be the Last of a Breed - NYTimes.com|date=9 January 1994|work=nytimes.com}}</ref> After 5 years at the [[East Village, Manhattan|East Village]] location, Dixon Place needed to expand. In order to accommodate a growing audience, Dixon Place moved to a larger space on the Bowery in 1991. The loft also served as living space for Covan.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2004/09/26/realestate/26HABI.html</ref> Expanded programming, along with an increased staff and audience, prompted another move in 1999, when Dixon Place became the resident company at the Vineyard Theater’s 26th Street space.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/nycs-dixon-place-moves-into-old-vineyard-theatre-82361|title=NYC's Dixon Place Moves Into Old Vineyard Theatre|work=Playbill}}</ref> Success in this professional environment led to the decision to secure a permanent home. In 2002, in partnership with a dedicated Board and a forward-thinking developer, Dixon Place purchased an industrial space on Chrystie Street in Lower Manhattan. After a 6-year capital project, Dixon Place's state-of-the-art laboratory theater and lounge, featuring expanded amenities for artists and audiences and new earned income for Dixon Place, had its Grand Opening in December 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeout.com/newyork/own-this-city-blog/new-venue-dixon-place-finally-gets-its-official-grand-opening|title=New venue: Dixon Place finally gets its official grand opening|work=Time Out New York}}</ref>
==Facility== In addition to a professional laboratory theater, the new space, designed by Meyer + Gifford Architects, includes numerous artist amenities The main-stage theater has column-free width for performance, as well as a sprung [[masonite]] floor, high ceilings, rigging points for aerial work, and state-of-the-art technical equipment. There is a separate rehearsal studio with a sprung [[marmoleum]] floor, and the spacious dressing room includes a private artist’s restroom and shower.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.studio-tl.com/projects_theatre/pt_dixonplace.html|title=Dixon Place - Studio T+L|work=studio-tl.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150121164157/http://www.studio-tl.com/projects_theatre/pt_dixonplace.html|archivedate=2015-01-21|df=}}</ref><ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/02/arts/dance/02kour.html</ref>
Dixon Place also includes a welcoming lounge. Set up as a for-profit subsidiary with a full liquor license, it is a new business model that subsidizes the theater's artistic programs. The lounge includes a gallery and a smaller stage that provides additional artistic outlets and day-time community space for educational programs and a meeting place for other organizations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bizbash.com/dixon_place_opening_150-seat_theater_on_l_e_s/new-york/story/12432#.VL-_AtLF98E|title=Dixon Place Opening 150-Seat Theater on L.E.S.|author=Anna Sekula|date=10 September 2008|work=BizBash}}</ref>
==Programming==
All of Dixon Place's programs have been developed out of a specific need that was not being met elsewhere.
===Commissions===
In 1994, Dixon Place began the Mondo Cane! Commissioning Program that supports 8 theater, dance and music creators annually by providing them with 1–3 months of workshop time, followed by 1–4 weeks of world premiere full-scale production performances. Mondo Cane! has offered commissions to such artists as [[The Civilians]], [[The Debate Society]] and [[Sibyl Kempson]]. In 2015, Dixon Place will present world premiere commissions by [[James Godwin]], [[Mark Dendy]], [[Marga Gomez]], [[Raja Feather Kelly]], [[Victor Morales (artist)|Victor Morales]], [[ANIMALS]], and [[Jessica Almasy]].
===Curated Series===
Dixon Place offers over 20 year-round, curated programs:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thevillager.com/villager_340/dixonplacerides.html|title=Dixon Place rides (and reads, and performs) again|work=thevillager.com}}</ref> * Mondo Cane! Commissioning Program – theater, music, and dance commissions; 7–8 per year. * Artists-in-Residence – 3–4 month residencies for emerging artists/ensembles; 3 per year. * Performance Works-In-Progress – new, developing work by theater, dance, music, and performance artists; ongoing. * Puppet Blok- new puppetry, mask, animation and other alternative forms; ongoing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theatermania.com/off-off-broadway/shows/puppet-blok_184508/|title=Puppet Blok! - Off-Off-Broadway - Tickets, Reviews, Info and More|work=theatermania}}</ref> * Carousel – a wide array of comic strip makers, graphic novelists, visual artists and luminaries presenting new work; 4–5 per year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://carouselslideshow.com/|title=Carousel|work=carouselslideshow.com}}</ref> * Little Theatre – OBIE award—winning series that presents experimental theater, performance art, music and dance; 10 per year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hbstudio.org/people-who-make-theatre-little-theatre-and-thisthat/|title=People Who Make Theatre: LITTLE THEATRE & THIS/THAT|work=HB Studio}}</ref> * Bindlestiff Open Stage Variety Show – an uncompromising theatrical experience that includes aerial artists, wire walkers, sword swallowers, Kung Fu juggling, clown bands, trained rats, and more; 10 per year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vaudevisuals.com/2013/01/vaudevisuals-interview-with-bindlestiff-open-stage-mc-and-co-producer-keith-nelson/|title=Vaudevisuals Interview with Bindlestiff Open Stage MC and Co-Producer Keith Nelson|work=VAUDE_VISUALS}}</ref> * No Holds Barred – a magical night featuring gifted professional and student aerial, circus, theater and dance artists, 3–6 per year.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/noholdsvariety|title=No Holds Barred variety presented by dixon place|work=Facebook}}</ref> * Crossing Boundaries – choreographers who cross cultural, geographical and disciplinary boundaries; 5–6 per year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dance-enthusiast.com/features/view/Impressions-of-Crossing-Boundaries-2013-06-04|title=Impressions of Crossing Boundaries|work=dance-enthusiast.com}}</ref> * Under Exposed – emerging choreographers, 6–8 per year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dance-enthusiast.com/community/events/view/Underexposed-at-Dixon-Place-Happening-Tomorrow-Sandy-has-left-the-building-2012-11-05-185500/|title=Underexposed at Dixon Place Happening Tomorrow!!!!! Sandy has left the building!|work=dance-enthusiast.com}}</ref> * Brink – a platform for innovative and investigatory choreographers to show longer, more developed works in progress; 5–6 per year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bombmagazine.org/article/6486/|title=BOMB Magazine — BRINK: Diana Crum and Katy Pyle by Lori DeGolyer|work=bombmagazine.org}}</ref> * Moving Men – choreography by both male and female choreographers working with only male dancers, 2–3 per year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theatermania.com/off-off-broadway/shows/moving-men_129199/|title=Moving Men - Off-Off-Broadway - Tickets, Reviews, Info and More|work=theatermania}}</ref> * NYC10 – a monthly dance project that gives 10 emerging dance companies up to 10 minutes to showcase their work; 5–6 per year.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nyc10dance.wordpress.com/|title=Welcome to NYC10|work=Welcome to NYC10}}</ref> * Gershwin Live at Dixon Place – an evolving 21st century salon, artists with fearless and distinctive voices are given free rein to present theater, film, cabaret, ghost stories, music and uncategorizable hybrids; monthly.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://stfortune.com/post/78443583906/st-fortune-and-gershwin-live-present-arryoya|title=- St. Fortune and Gershwin Live Present… ARRYOYA...|work=stfortune.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150121183635/http://stfortune.com/post/78443583906/st-fortune-and-gershwin-live-present-arryoya|archivedate=2015-01-21|df=}}</ref> * Experiments & Disorders – fiction, nonfiction, poetry and performance texts by adventurous, cross-genre, established and emerging writers; 6–8 per year -- curated by [[Christen Clifford]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://etruscanpress.org/dv/event/lynn-lurie-featuring-in-experiments-disorders/|title=Lynn Lurie Featuring in Experiments & Disorders - Etruscan Press|work=Etruscan Press}}</ref> * QT – a quarterly literary series exploring the rich lives of LGBTQ writers; 3 per year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeout.com/newyork/things-to-do/qt-a-queer-text-reading|title=QT: A Queer Text Reading|work=Time Out New York}}</ref> * Communitas – this literary series brings together writers, authors, readers, storytellers, and audiences from the many communities of New York City and beyond to showcase what’s next for the city; 3 per year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wherevent.com/detail/Federico-Hewson-Communitas-at-Dixon-Place-with-Federico-Hewson-and-Christopher-Artell|title=Communitas at Dixon Place with Federico Hewson and Christopher Artell|work=wherevent.com}}</ref> * Secret City – part revival, part salon, part spectacle, this ‘service’ features performance, visual art, music, food, and literature, designed to inspire, invigorate and amaze vibrant and creative communities of New York City; monthly.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thesecretcity.org/events/|title=Events - The Secret City|work=The Secret City}}</ref> * Lounge Music– free, acoustic music of all genres; 4–6 nights per week. * The Gallery – rotating solo and group exhibitions with an emphasis on showcasing work by NYC-based artists. * HOT! The NYC Celebration of Queer Culture – annual summer festival featuring GLBTQ works from across genres, for 23 years and counting.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/23rd-Annual-HOT-the-NYC-Celebration-of-Queer-Culture-at-Dixon-Place-75-82-20140620|title=23rd Annual HOT!, the NYC Celebration of Queer Culture, at Dixon Place, 7/5-8/2|author=BWW News Desk|work=BroadwayWorld.com}}</ref> * Murrin Award (“Tommies”) – The [[Tom Murrin]] Performance Award is an annual award selected by a panel of artistic directors and producers granted to an emerging artist who embodies Tom’s generous artistic spirit &and gift for unearthing big, meaningful ideas by creating enlightening performance. First awarded in 2013 to ANIMALS ([[Nikki Calonge]], [[Michael De Angelis]] and [[Mike Mikos]]) and in 2014 to [[Andrew Schneider]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Andrew-Schneider-to-Receive-2014-Tom-Murrin-Performance-Award-20140409|title=Andrew Schneider to Receive 2014 Tom Murrin Performance Award|author=BWW News Desk|work=BroadwayWorld.com}}</ref>
==Community Outreach (CECO)== Begun in 2000, the Cultural Education & Community Outreach Program (CECO) provides rare artistic opportunities for culturally under-served senior citizens and youth living in Lower Manhattan, at no cost to the participants. CECO has brought theater, writing, dance and film/video workshops to local youth in collaboration with such partners as [[Urban Arts Partnership]], [[New Design High School]], [[University Settlement]], [[Tompkins Square Middle School]] and [[The School for Global Leaders]]; and to senior citizens, collaborating with [[Services & Advocacy for GLBT Elders (SAGE)]], [[Sirovich Senior Center]] and [[Bowery Residents Committee (BRC) Senior Center-Chinatown]]. With this program, Dixon Place has reached beyond the artist community to include the voices of low-to-moderate income young and elderly neighbors. The free workshops focus on performing, writing, movement, and music, culminating in public performances. This program enables the participants to experience artistic expression, discover their creative voices, develop their own theatrical works and perform in front of supportive audiences.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QIrktUOLkCU|title=CECO - 06/08/14|work=YouTube}}</ref>
==Awards==
In 1990, [[The Village Voice]] awarded Dixon Place a special [[OBIE]] Award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/obies/index/1990/|title=New York Obies Theater Awards|work=villagevoice.com}}</ref> * 1989: Covan was given a New York Dance and Performance Award—–a "[[Bessie Awards|Bessie]]"—–for service to the community.<ref>https://www.dancenyc.nyc/images/Bessie%20Archive.pdf</ref> * 1998: Dixon Place received the [[City University of New York]]’s [[Edwin Booth Award]] for excellence in theater.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/nys-dixon-place-receives-1999-edwin-booth-award-ceremony-april-12-81200/print|title=NY's Dixon Place Receives 1999 Edwin Booth Award Ceremony, April 12 - Playbill.com|work=playbill.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924202300/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/nys-dixon-place-receives-1999-edwin-booth-award-ceremony-april-12-81200/print|archivedate=2015-09-24|df=}}</ref> * 1999: Covan was awarded The Voice’s [[Ross Wetzsteon Award]] for contributions to the community.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/obies/index/1999/|title=New York Obies Theater Awards|work=villagevoice.com}}</ref> * 2002: Covan received the [[Brooklyn Arts Exchange]] [[BAXten Award]] for paving the way for others through arts administration.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://events.bax.org/special/arts-artists-progress-awards-history/|title=Arts & Artists In Progress Awards History|work=Events @ BAX}}</ref> * 2004: Dixon Place was awarded the [[Alliance of New York State Arts Organization]]’s [[Celebrate the Arts Award]] for outstanding contributions to the state of New York. * 2010: The organization was given the [[Stewardship Award]] by the [[New York Innovative Theater Foundation]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nyitawards.com/news/newsitem.asp?storyid=181|title=Honorary IT Awards to Go to Several Major Players in Off-Off Community - News from the IT Awards|work=nyitawards.com}}</ref>
==Sources of funding== Private and Corporate Support for Dixon Place is provided by: [[Axe-Houghton Foundation]], [[Bernstein Family Foundation]], [[New York Department of Cultural Affairs]], [[Doris Duke Foundation]], [[Harkness Foundation for Dance]], [[The Jim Henson Foundation]], [[Jerome Foundation]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jeromefdn.org/grantees/new-project-130|title=Open Channels / Dixon Place - Support for Emerging Mondo Cane! Commissioned Artists & Artists-in-Residence - The Jerome Foundation|work=jeromefdn.org}}</ref> [[Andrew W. Mellon Foundation]], [[Mertz Gilmore Foundation]], [[Jerome Robbins Foundation]], [[Fan Fox & Leslie R. Samuels Foundation]], [[New York State Council on the Arts]], [[The Peg Santvoord Foundation]], [[The Shubert Foundation]].
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.dixonplace.org}}
